instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Recognizing HD
threads.message: Hello guys. This board came to me with no life. Someone had already poked around it. I reballed SMC, replaced battery current sensing resistors and board started. It does not see HDD though. Replaced cable with known good one, still same. Mesauring around I found <RESISTOR>R4535</RESISTOR> was bad so I replaced it. Same result. I decided then just to replace all caps (<CAPACITOR>C4510</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C4511</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C4515</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C4516</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C4534</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C4533</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C4514</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C4519</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C4535</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C4536</CAPACITOR>) still same. Replaced <CHIP>U4510</CHIP>, still same. Chip is getting power on VDD. EN signal is around 1,5V, which I think is low. Tried forcing it to 3.3V via jumper wire, but it still does not see the drive. What else could I verify before declaring dead PCH?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Recognizing HD
threads.message:
<CHIP>U4510</CHIP> is powered from 1.5V, does not accept 3V on any pin.
That is the reason of series caps.
You could killed the chip forcing enable signal with 3V; change <CHIP>U4510</CHIP>, to discard this problem.

If you get <SIGNAL>5V_S0_HDD</SIGNAL> at J4501 and <CHIP>U4510</CHIP> is good, then the problem is on the PCH side.
Change the series caps on that side too.
